timeline.subject: Claudatte femme Nicolas Chollat
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal orders arrest of suspect

timeline.subject: Claudatte femme Nicolas Chollat
timeline.details: First interrogation - denials and natural explanations

timeline.subject: Claudatte femme Nicolas Chollat
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Claudatte femme Nicolas Chollat
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture - thumbscrews, rack, tourtillons - limited confession then retracted

timeline.subject: Claudatte femme Nicolas Chollat
timeline.details: Further torture - doctor notes extreme endurance - finally confesses to being witch, using powder, attending sabbat, killing daughter of Nicolas Jacquot

timeline.subject: Claudatte femme Nicolas Chollat
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for death sentence, to feel fire before strangulation, and power to torture for accomplice names

timeline.subject: Claudatte femme Nicolas Chollat
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves, subject to voluntary repetition of confessions

timeline.subject: Claudatte femme Nicolas Chollat
timeline.details: Repeated confession voluntarily - now said attended sabbat twice, still couldn't recognize accomplices

methods: tourtillons (applied to legs, thighs, and arms)

prior_accusations.accuser_name: Anne wife of Thiebault Hannast (sister of accused)
prior_accusations.context: Sister called her 'vrayement une sorciere, ou qu'il n'y en avoit point au monde' approximately 7 years before trial
Said 'Ceste sorciere nous fera beaucoups de mal' and believed she caused his brother's year-long illness, approximately 7 years before trial

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudatte femme Nicolas Chollat
notable_quotes.french: sinon il s'en donroit bien tost de garde
notable_quotes.english: if not he would soon beware of it
notable_quotes.context: Threat to Demenge Loys about compensation for foal in her field

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudatte femme Nicolas Chollat
notable_quotes.french: qu'il ne se menne sy mal de poeur qu'il ne s'en repente
notable_quotes.english: that he not behave so badly for fear he would repent it
notable_quotes.context: Threat to Nicolas Loys about reproaching her for not pasturing animals

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Chollat (husband)
notable_quotes.french: mais qu'il eust aultant aymé qu'elle l'eust laissé qu'aussy bien s'en alloit il mourir au diable
notable_quotes.english: but that he would have preferred she leave it alone as it was going to die to the devil anyway
notable_quotes.context: Husband's comment about wife medicating sick calf, suggesting suspicion of her

notable_quotes.speaker: Anthoine Chollat (brother-in-law)
notable_quotes.french: Ceste sorciere nous fera beaucoups de mal
notable_quotes.english: This witch will do us much harm
notable_quotes.context: Comment about Claudatte approximately 7 years before trial

notable_quotes.speaker: Anne wife of Thiebault Hannast (sister)
notable_quotes.french: qu'icelle estoit vrayement une sorciere, ou qu'il n'y en avoit point au monde
notable_quotes.english: that she was truly a witch, or there were none in the world
notable_quotes.context: Sister's comment about Claudatte approximately 7 years before trial

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Jacquot (brother-in-law, defending)
notable_quotes.french: aucunes languardees de femmes telles que celle de Jean de St. George et de Nicolas de Perxonne dudit Repas en mettent leurs langues en oueuvres, et en disent leurs bonnes goulées comme il leur plaist
notable_quotes.english: some gossiping women such as that of Jean de St. George and Nicolas de Perxonne of said Repas put their tongues to work, and say their good mouthfuls as it pleases them
notable_quotes.context: Defending Claudatte against accusations since St. Jean's day

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudatte femme Nicolas Chollat
notable_quotes.french: que sadite soeur luy mettoit un beau chappeau sur la teste de la declairer comme elle faisoit qu'elle estoit sorciere
notable_quotes.english: that her said sister put a beautiful hat on her head by declaring as she did that she was a witch
notable_quotes.context: Claudatte's response about her sister calling her 'genatte' 33 years before

notable_quotes.speaker: Daughter of Nicolas Jacquot
notable_quotes.context: What the child called Claudatte's children before she allegedly killed the girl - from Claudatte's confession

economic_context.details: Multiple economic disputes: debt of 4 gros owed to Royne; disputes over animal pasturing fees; Nicolas Chollat's position as paistre of animals; dispute over guard of 'menues bestes' where mother of witness 24 outbid Claudatte's husband; business arrangement over cow in milk with Nicolas de Perxuanne; servant allegedly stealing grain and taking to Claudatte's house; wheat sales refusal; horse sale payment dispute with Thiebault Hannast. Economic tensions central to accusations.

material_culture.context: Claudatte drove foal out with stick
Red horned beasts - communal animals under guard
Payment to recover cow and calf
Strong waters applied to blind daughter's eyes
Magical powder used for maléfices (from confession)
Claudatte found unconscious in pig-muck in stables

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial and residence of accused and most witnesses
Market location where debt dispute occurred; location of court; residence of witness 1
Where witness 6 resided for many years after marriage before returning to Repas
Location where man knew how to treat wolf-savaged animals
Origin of Jean Rachamp, servant who told cat story
Blamont market where debt dispute occurred
Where witnesses were working when harms occurred
Where Claudatte became unconscious and allegedly devil appeared to her
Unspecified location where Claudatte confessed to attending sabbat twice
Location of Change de Nancy court that approved torture and execution

historical_context.military_details: Witness 19 mentions 'passage of late duc de Bouillon's army' some two years before his testimony (approximately 1603)
weather_events: torbillon (whirlwind) that surrounded Nicolas de Perxuanne in fields
animal_predation: Wolf attacks on cow and goat belonging to Royne femme Jean de St. George
Multiple references to wolf savaging domestic animals
economic_hardship_indicators: Debt disputes over small amounts (4 gros)
Competition for paid positions (paistre, guard of animals)
Economic value of animals critical (15-21 ecus for horses)
religious_calendar_references: St. George's day (mentioned as timing reference)
Christmas (mentioned as end of servant's year)

legal_context.redress_outcome: In case of Jean de St. George accusing her over calf death, Claudatte sought to take them before justice at Blamont, but they did not wish to plead. Also threatened to take Jean Rachamp (servant) to court at Blamont over cat accusation but never followed through.

change_de_nancy.modification_details: Approved torture (21 Oct 1605) and death sentence with modification that she should 'feel fire bien vivement before being strangled' (3 Nov 1605), subject to voluntary repetition of confessions

hearsay_chains.content: Small animals fled from flame and many at Repas suspected Claudatte
Ceste sorciere nous fera beaucoups de mal - brother believed she caused year-long illness
Claudatte was truly a witch or there were none in the world
Husband had suspicion of sorcery against wife regarding sick calf
Story of cat attacking horse and accusation of Claudatte transforming into cat

hearsay_chains.source: aucuns dudit Repas (some people of Repas)
hearsay_chains.content: Others tried to convince her Claudatte caused animal deaths but she had no opinion
Husband told her there was talk of accusing Claudatte at wheat harvest
Warned that servant was stealing grain and taking to Claudatte's house

emotional_state_notes: Described herself as 'trop bonne et trop molle femme' (too good and too soft a woman)
Resisted torture extensively - doctor noted extreme endurance suggested unnatural explanation
Made promises to confess if released from torture then continued denials
Only confessed after repeated extreme torture including whole turn of rack

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: In bean-picking incident said witness's daughter asked her own daughter to enter garden, quarrel was minor
In case of cow recovery, said they were glad to return it since short of feed
Said sister called her 'genatte' 33 years before 'par hayne' (out of hatred) after she was found unconscious in pig-muck in stables
Brother-in-law defended her, saying it was just 'languardees de femmes' (women's gossip) from wives of Jean de St. George and Nicolas de Perxonne

extraction_metadata.notes: Exceptionally detailed trial with 27 witnesses providing extensive testimony. Reputation ranged from 8-33 years. Multiple economic disputes central to accusations. Accused showed remarkable resistance to torture - doctor noted unusual endurance. Confessed only under extreme torture (whole turn of rack, tourtillons), initially retracted, then renewed confession voluntarily before execution. Unable to name accomplices at sabbat despite pressure. Rich detail on daily economic life, animal husbandry, communal pasturing systems, debt relations, and family tensions. Notable that accused's own sister and brother-in-law testified against her (witnesses 11, 12) while another brother-in-law defended her (witness 18). Cat transformation story widely circulated but denied. Executed November 5, 1605 - same day as final interrogation.
